{{Infobox person | name = Daniel Irujo Urra | image = Daniel Irujo.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Daniel Irujo Urra | birth_date = 1862 | birth_place = [[Estella-Lizarra|Estella]], Spain | death_date = 1911 | death_place = Estella, Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = lawyer | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = lawyer, scholar, local self-government official | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]], [[Basque nationalism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Alejandro María Daniel Irujo Urra''' (1862-1911) was a Spanish lawyer. In popular discourse he is known as father of [[Manuel Irujo y Ollo|Manuel Irujo Ollo]], a Basque political leader. In scholarly historiographic realm he is acknowledged mostly as defense attorney of [[Sabino Arana]] during his trials of 1896 and 1902. Politically Irujo is considered a typical case of an identity located in-between [[Carlism]] and emerging Spain's peripheral nationalisms, in this case the [[Basque nationalism|Basque one]].
==Family and youth== [[File:Fusilamientos de Estella.jpg|thumb|left|[[Estella-Lizarra|Estella]], [[First Carlist War]]]] Origins of the Irujo family are not clear; some claim they descended from a noble Urra family of [[Améscoa Baja|Améscoa]] in Western [[Navarre]].<ref>Ángel García-Sanz Marcotegui, ''La adscripción ideológica de los antepasados de Manuel Irujo Ollo'', [in:] ''Vasconia. Cuadernos de historia – geografía'' 32 (2002), p. 22</ref> It is certain that in the mid-18th century one branch of the Irujos<ref>one of them settled in Pamplona; its descandant was Daniel Irujo Armendáriz (1874-1927), in 1904-1909 serving as alcalde of Pamplona, not to be confused with Daniel Irujo Urra</ref> lived in [[Tafalla]]; Daniel’s grandfather, [[Matías Irujo Pascual]] (1757-1832),<ref>compare ''Matías de Irujo Pascual'' entry, [in:] ''Geni'' genealogical service, available [https://www.geni.com/people/Mat%C3%ADas-de-Irujo-Pascual/6000000018579300996 here]</ref> apart from having been an [[Espadrille|alpargatero]] owned some 9 ha of vineyards and 12 ha of arable land; he was rich enough to build an own house in the city.<ref>Angel Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui, ''Daniel Irujo Urra: 1862-1911: el carlo-nacionalismo imposible del defensor de Sabino Arana. Ensayo y testimonio'', Tafalla 1995, {{ISBN|9788476812136}}, p. 22</ref> Married<ref>in 1779 to María Teresa Apastegui (1760-1826)</ref> he had 11 children, born between 1780 and 1803; all except one settled on the rural economy.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 23</ref> It is not clear what language was spoken in the family; in the late 18th century Tafalla remained on the borderlines of [[Basque language|Basque]]-speaking zone.<ref>José María Esparza Zabalegui, ''Lexícografía de Tafalla'', [in:] ''Cuadernos de Etnolgía y Etnografía de Navarra'' 11/31 (1979), p. 185</ref> The youngest son and Daniel’s father, [[Manuel Irujo Apastegui]] (1803-1871), entered the [[Pamplona]] seminar but abandoned it<ref name="auto">García-Sanz Marcotegui 2002, p. 21</ref> and completed law in [[Zaragoza]], where he initially practiced.<ref>in the office of a known lawyer, Manuel Solano, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 26</ref> During the [[First Carlist War]] he joined the legitimists holding some admin posts in [[Estella-Lizarra|Estella]]<ref>in 1838 he was member of Diputación Provisional Carlista for Navarre and most likely resided in Estella, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 26. Some documents of the suggest by his opponents he was considered one of the among most influential Navarrese Carlists, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 27</ref> and suffered some repression afterwards, when back in Tafalla.<ref>perhaps he spent some time on exile episod in France. Some of his Tafalla estates were expropriated, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 27-28</ref> This did not prevent his law practice and career in local administration,<ref>in 1843 he was nominated by the ayntamiento to Junta de Escuelas; in the mid-1840s he served as teniente de alcade, with his older brother serving as alcalde</ref> though he failed in a [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] bid.<ref name="auto"/>
In 1850 Manuel married Engracia Urra Jordan (1825-1885), daughter to an Estella official, whom he probably met during the war.<ref>García-Sanz Marcotegui 2002, p. 22</ref> The couple left Tafalla – according to some accounts due to an anti-Carlist backlash suffered<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 21</ref> – and moved to the bride’s house in Estella. Engaged in local business,<ref>e.g. until death he was president of the board of La Agrícola, in 1917 succeeded by his grandson Manuel, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 101</ref> Manuel went on as lawyer.<ref>e.g. he representing local self-government and state in disputes against each other, which certainly helped him to learn the countryside specifics</ref> In the 1860s elected as mayor for procedural reasons he could not assume the post,<ref>in 1857 he was elected to ayuntamiento but could not exercise as at the same time he was the municipal juez suplemente. In 1862 he was elected again and nominated alcalde; again he preferred retain the juez post and renounced the alcaldia, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 22, 31, 32</ref> yet in 1866 he was elected to [[:es:Diputación Foral de Navarra|Navarrese Diputación Provincial]],<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 33</ref> due to poor health barely serving.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 34</ref> Manuel and Engracia had 5 children, born between 1850 and 1862; Daniel was the only surviving son.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 29</ref> It is not clear whether the family spoke Basque or Spanish; in Estella of the time only few spoke "en vasco".<ref>Estella spoke Basque in the late 18th century, but in 1842 "en Estella los jovenes no hablan en vasco, solo los viejos de los pueblos cercanos conocen ya ese idioma", José María Satrustegi Zubeldia, ''El euskera en Tierra Estella'', [in:] ''Euskera'' 36/1 (1991), p. 120. In the late 19th century some Basque persisted among some people in Sierra de Urbasa and Sierra de Andia, Satrustegi 1991, pp. 121-122</ref> [[File:Sabin Arana, Urduñako ikastetxea, 1878-1879.jpg|thumb|Orduña pupils, 1870s]] The young Alejandro María Daniel Irujo<ref>''Manuel de Irujo sin florituras. Conversación mantenida en 1975 con D. Manuel de Irujo por Iñaki Anasagasti'', p. 16, available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/files/manuel_de_irujo.doc here]</ref> and his siblings were brought up in religious ambience.<ref>e.g. in 1865 Manuel Irujo in name of his own and all family members signed an adddress to the Pope and declared 20 reales per every family member for a related fundraising collection, ''El Pensamiento Español'' 08.09.65, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029689578&page=1 here], also Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 50</ref> In the mid-1870s he was sent away from Estella, then a Carlist capital, to the [[Lestelle-Bétharram|Bétharram]] college near [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]. Prior to 1876 he moved to the [[Jesuit]] [[Orduña-Urduña|Orduña]] establishment,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 43</ref> where he met the likes of Sabino Arana<ref>some claim that Irujo and Arana were schoolgroup, a theory doubted by others as Arana was 3 years Irujo’s junior; because of the age difference, their friendship was probably not very close, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 44</ref> and [[Juan Olazábal Ramery|Juan Olazábal]].<ref>''Euskera: se empieza inventando un idioma'', [in:] ''Bye Bye Spain'' service, available [http://nacionalismo.blogs.com/byebyespain/2005/02/euskera_se_empi.html here]</ref> In 1878 he commenced law studies in [[Valladolid]], graduating in derecho civíl y canónico in 1882.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 44-46. Another source claims he graduated in 1885, ''Inocencia de un patriota. Notable defensa del fundador del partido nacionalista Don Sabino de Arana y Goiri ante el Tribunal por el ilustre Abogado D. Daniel de Irujo'', Buenos Aires 1913, p. 5</ref> Evading military service,<ref>not sure on what basis, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 46</ref> in 1883 he settled in Pamplona. Employed by the law office of his brother-in-law,<ref>in 1880 Estanislao Aranzadi married Irujo’s sister. Upon his settlement in Pamplona, Irujo lived in their house, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 46</ref> he set up his own office following a move back to Estella in 1885.<ref>''Lau-buru'' 20.12.85, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=6015466&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1890 Daniel married Aniana Ollo Elordi (1866-1950), Estella-born daughter of a local pharmacist and concejal.<ref>she was daughter to Alsasua-born Eusebio Ollo Miranda and Manilla-born Carolina Elordi, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 49</ref> The couple had 10 children, born between 1891 and 1910.<ref>two of them died in early infancy</ref> Most were engaged in Basque nationalist politics. The best known, Manuel, was minister in the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican]] government during the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]]. Also other sons held posts in Basque Republican administration,<ref>Andres was responsible for re-organisation of Basque security forces. Some account highlight his role in bringing order to the militia-dominated security troops and their later organized withdrawal. Others highlight his role in rounding up political enemies, Pablo Larraz Andía, Víctor Sierra-Sesumaga (eds.), ''Requetés. De las trincheras al olvidio'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788499700465}}, p. 286. Pello is known mostly for facilitaing escape of an endangered archbishop to the Nationalist zone, Iñaki Egaña, ''Quién es quién en la historia del país de los vascos'', Tafalla 2005, {{ISBN|9788481363999}}, p. 263</ref> two of them – [[:es:Andrés de Irujo|Andrés]] and [[:es:Pello Irujo|Pello]] - known for their contribution to the Basque culture during exile years<ref>most of the family were arrested by the Nationalists either in Navarre on in Gipúzkoa in 1936, many of them sentenced to death. Females were exchanged for prisoners held by the Republicans in 1937, males were released in 1938. Jesús de Galíndez, ''Los vascos en el Madrid sitiado: memorias del Partido Nacionalista Vasco y de la Delegación de Euzkadi en Madrid desde septiembre de 1936 a mayo de 1937'', Tafalla 1002, {{ISBN|9788481363340}}, p. 142</ref> in [[Southern America]].<ref>Iñaki Egaña, ''Diccionario histórico-político de Euskal Herria'', Tafalla 1996, {{ISBN|9788481360394}}, p. 447, Josu Checa, ''Prólogo a la presente edición'', [in:] Manuel Irujo Ollo, ''Inglaterra y los vascos'', Tafalla 2004, {{ISBN|8481363928}}, pp. 10-11. For exile record of Irujo’s widow see ''Aniana Ollo de Irujo'' entry, [in:] ''exiliadosrepublicanos'' service, available [http://www.exiliadosrepublicanos.info/es/content/aniana-ollo-de-irujo here]</ref> Some lived long enough to return to Spain following the death of [[Francisco Franco|Franco]].
==Early career== [[File:Insurrección carlista, ataque y defensa de Estella.jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Estella-Lizarra|Estella]], [[Third Carlist War]]]] In historiography political antecedents of Daniel are summarized as "scarcely homogeneous".<ref name="auto"/> Some of his paternal uncles engaged in Tafallese [[:es:Cristino|Cristinos]] militia and ancestors of his wife were distinguished Estella [[Liberalism in Spain|Liberals]].<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 50-2 García-Sanz Marcotegui 2002, pp. 34-5</ref> It is clear, however, that the Carlist leaning prevailed; apart from Daniel’s father and other paternal uncles<ref>especially the older brother of Manuel, Matías, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 22-25</ref> also his maternal uncle, Sebastián Urra Jordán, held various posts in the party and represented it in the Cortes.<ref>a priest since 1854, he was professor at the Pamplona seminar in the 1860s. Actively engaged in Carlist administration in Navarre during the war, he was member of Diputación Foral del Reino de Navarra. Briefly on exile, since 1884 served as a catehdral canon in León</ref> As it was him appointed by late Manuel cabezalero of his children,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 35</ref> Urra has contributed to their Carlist outlook.<ref>García-Sanz Marcotegui 2002, pp. 24-25</ref> Already as a child in [[Third Carlist War|Carlist-held Estella]] Daniel used to collect unexploded cartridges fired by the governmental troops to make sure they do not hurt the Carlists,<ref>Paul Vignaux, ''Manuel de Irujo: ministre de la République dans la guerre d'Espagne, 1936-1939'', Paris 1986, {{ISBN|9782701011288}}, p. 84, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 43</ref> and he admitted to having "sucked" Carlism when a child.<ref>as he admitted later, "había yo mamado el carlismo, como también vosostros lo mamasteis", quoted after Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 59</ref> Education in Orduña college, managed by the Jesuits, is likely to have reinforced this stand; also during academic years in Valladolid Irujo remained in the company of Carlism-minded friends.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 44</ref>
Nothing is known about Irujo’s engagement either in the Carlist youth organization or in the party structures in the 1880s. However, he demonstrated particular interest in one element of the Carlist political program: restoration of traditional legal provincial establishments, the [[fueros]]. He seemed heavily influenced by his brother-in-law Estanislao Aranzadi, co-founder of [[:es:Asociación Euskara de Navarra|Asociación Euskara de Navarra]] and its daily, ''Lau-buru'';<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 102</ref> politically the grouping tended to fuerismo,<ref>in 1883 ''Lau-Buru'' referred to Irujo as a close friend, ''Lau-Buru'' 05.06.83, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=6014029&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> with return to foral regime placed as the central if not exclusive objective.<ref>the fueristas were hostile to Carlism; they rather considered the movement "mausoleum of the past", somewhat stuck in a millenarian format, compare ''Lau-Buru'' 17.09.86, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=6015178&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Apart from personal links and subscription to fuerista periodicals Irujo did not engage politically<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 48</ref> before in 1887 he was offered a job in the [[University of Deusto|Jesuit Deusto college]].<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 57, 207</ref> He assumed the chair of Procedimientos Judiciales y Práctica Forense and settled in [[Bilbao]] either that year or the following one. His focus on fueros matured into a treaty, produced at unspecified time though most likely in the mid-1890s, and intended as sort of a textbook for his Deusto disciples.<ref>the manual was titled ''¡Un hombre! Historia del Derecho vásco, escrita por el mismo y explicada a sus discípulos''. The text was published in 1932 by one of Irujo’s disciples. It diivded the history of the region into 3 parts: 1) prior to incorporation into Castille, 2) until 1839, and 3) after 1839. Present-day scholars considers the 1932 printout a reliable insight into Irujo’s views, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 57-9</ref> It advanced a thesis that until 1839 Navarre and the [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]] enjoyed the status of sovereign entities, united with the rest of peninsula mostly by means of personal union. [[File:HJK.146.12.JPG|thumb|160px|[[Joaquin Llorens Fernandez de Cordoba|Joaquin Llorens]]]] In 1893 Navarre was rocked by the so-called [[:es:Gamazada|Gamazada]], opposition to a ministerial attempt to scrap remnants of the provincial fiscal autonomy. The Carlist deputy to the Cortes from Estella, [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]], in name of "nosotros, fueristas y regionalistas"<ref>María del Mar Larraza Micheltorena, ''La Gamazada en el contexto de la política navarra de fin de siglo'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 56/204 (1995), pp. 188-189</ref> voiced against the project in the parliament, joined by another Carlist and the only non-Navarrese deputy who voted against it, [[Joaquín Lloréns Fernández de Cordoba|Joaquín Llorens]].<ref>Angel García-Sanz Marcotegui, ''La insurrección fuerista en 1893. Foralismo oficial vesus foralismo popular durante la Gamazada'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 696</ref> Irujo most likely remained in touch with the two; when Llorens was cheered in Estella upon return from Madrid, he delivered his triumphant addresses from the balcony of Irujo’s house.<ref>''El Tradicionalista'' 29.09.93, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=6012402&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Similarly, the following year Irujo was in [[Castejón, Navarre|Castejón]], the first major Navarrese train station, organizing welcome of the Navarrese diputación returning from negotiations in [[Madrid]].<ref>Gorka Fuentes Megina, ''El nacionalismo vasco en "El Eco de Navarra"'' [MA thesis Universidad Navarra], Pamplona 2013, pp. 20-21. In his article, published 9 years later and intended as homage to Arana, Irujo described the Castejon event as an exclusively nationalist affair, García-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 81-82</ref>
==Arana link== [[File:Bizkaitarra, 1894ko iraila.jpg|thumb|160px|left|''[[:es:Bizkaitarra|Bizkaitarra]]'', 1894]] When in Bilbao Irujo resumed his friendship with the Arana brothers and in 1894 he subscribed to their review ''[[:es:Bizkaitarra|Bizkaitarra]]'',<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 61</ref> though he did not join the early Basque nationalist organisation, [[:eu:Euskeldun Batzokija|Euskeldun Batzokija]]. During Gamazada he introduced Arana to the Navarrese fueristas; it was also in 1894 that at one point, taken over by Arana’s harangue, he declared "I am your man, though I keep being a Carlist".<ref>"soy de los tuyos, peró sin dejar de ser carlista". In a nutshell, his view on Vascongadas and Navarre towards Spain was "unidad de Rey e independencia de Reino", Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 59-61</ref> His relations with the Aranas got closer; when in 1895 they faced trial, charged with multiple offences related to reportedly Basque-nationalist, anti-Spanish background,<ref>in 1895 there were lawsuits planned against Arana, for assault on Filomena Soltura, for articles published on 21.07.95 in ''Bizkaitarra'', for his responsibility as president of Euskeldun Batzokija and for an anonymous article published on 05.09.95 (Arana refused to disclose its author), Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 61</ref> Irujo was initially supposed to defend [[Luis Arana]] in court.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 64-64</ref> The plan was changed and in 1896 he defended Sabino Arana, freed on bail.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 64</ref> Irujo’s defense line was that Arana violated no law;<ref>Irujo’s speech (or its version) went to print in 1913 as ''Inocencia de un patriota. Notable defensa del fundador del partido nacionalista Don Sabino de Arana y Goiri ante el Tribunal por el ilustre Abogado D. Daniel de Irujo''</ref> he went on to claim that his client campaigned against 1841 regulations, which he was perfectly entitled to do, apart from representing legitimate aspirations of "pueblo euskaldun", embodied in the God and Old Rights slogan.<ref>Elías Amézaga, ''Biografía sentimental de Sabino Arana'', Tafalla 2003, {{ISBN|9788481362725}}, p. 264</ref> With Irujo fully successful, Arana was absolved.<ref>Fuentes Megina 2013, pp. 26-27</ref>
In the late 1890s Irujo and the Aranas got even closer. In 1897 Irujo was asked to review ''El Partido Carlista y los Fueros Vasko-Nabarros'', a pamphlet written by Arana and denouncing the Carlist vision as "plain regionalism".<ref>detailed discussion in José Ignacio Fínez García, ''Fuerismo tradicionalista y nacionalismo vasco'' [MA thesis Universidad de Salamanca], Salamanca 2013, pp. 83-93</ref> Formally Irujo was to ensure that the document provides no basis for legal action;<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 72</ref> it is neither clear whether he contributed to the political content nor how he reconciled the task with his Carlist identity.<ref>one scholar claims that appearance of ''El Partido Carlista y los Fueros Vasko-Nabarros'' changed Carlist perception of the nascent Basque political movement; until 1897 Carlism did not consider the Basque nationalism any force to be reckoned with, Fínez García 2013, p. 94</ref> He helped the Aranas also otherwise, e.g. propagating their new periodical, ''Berritarra'', in Estella, or contributing to pro-nationalist turn of a Pamplona daily ''[[:eu:El Fuerista|El Fuerista]]''.<ref>Irujo mediated between Arana and jefe of the daily, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 73. ''El Fuerista'' was originally founded in 1888 as a daily of an ofshoot Carlist branch, the Integrists, compare ''El Fuerista'' entry, [in:] Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia online, available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/46428 here]</ref> However, Irujo fell short of open political access to the Aranistas and their [[Partido Nacionalista Vasco]]. Prior to the 1898 elections to the [[:es:Diputación Foral de Vizcaya|Biscay diputación provincial]] Sabino Arana suggested that Irujo runs as his representative, but the latter declined the offer.<ref>Mauro Elizondo, ''Sabino Arana. El hombre y su trayectoria'', Bilbao 1992, {{ISBN|8488379021}}, p. 27</ref> His exact views are not clear; it is not known what his opinion was about the conflict and rapprochement between the Aranistas and [[Euskalerriacos]] or general twists and turns of the PNV strategy. At some point between 1899 and 1902 he entered [[Centro Vasco]] in Bilbao and subscribed to militant nationalist periodicals, ''La Patria'' and ''Euskalduna''.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 73</ref> [[File:Sabino Arana in Larrinaga prison, 1895.jpg|thumb|[[Sabino Arana|Arana]] in prison]] In 1902 Sabino Arana was detained in relation to a telegram message he intended to send to [[Theodore Roosevelt|president Roosevelt]], congratulating him on recognition of [[Cuba]], until 1898 the Spanish possession. The charges advanced referred to assault on Spanish territorial integrity. The defendant again asked Irujo to represent him. In general terms the defense mounted was very much similar to that of 1896, pointing to Basque rights and revocation of the 1840s regulations;<ref>"Arana no busca la independencia sino el estado de libertades anterior a 1839; no existe delito en el telegrama puesto que no se cursó", quoted after Javier G. Chamorro, ''Bitarte: humanidades e historia del conflicto vasco-navarro'' , s.l. 2009, {{ISBN|9788461307111}}, p. 204</ref> Irujo reiterated his claim that nationalism was not equal to separatism.<ref>Arantzazu Ametzaga Iribarren, ''Sabino Arana Goiri y su abogado defensor, Daniel Irujo Urra, juicio de 1896'', [in:] ''Nabarralde'' service, available [http://www.nabarralde.com/eu/nabarmena/13212-sabino-arana-goiri-y-su-abogado-defensor-daniel-irujo-urra-juicio-de-1896 here]</ref> In terms of specific charges he argued that the telegram message intended expressed admiration and nothing more.<ref>Amézaga 2003, p. 269</ref> At the final stage aided by Teodoro Aguirre,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 74, José Antonio de Aguirre y Lecube, ''Escape Via Berlin: Eluding Franco in Hitler's Europe'', Reno 1944, p. 3</ref> Irujo again emerged triumphant; the defendant was acquitted.<ref>1902 Irujo defended also other in other lawsuits, namely against Centro Vasco and one of its members, Dámaso Arana; he was successful in both, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 76-7</ref> He refused to charge his client<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 76</ref> and maintained close friendship with Sabino Arana until the latter’s death in 1903.<ref>following the death of Arana Irujo published one of his very few known literary pieces known, ''La bandera nacionalista vulgo Bikaitarra'', reproduced in Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 80</ref>
==Estella oak affair== [[File:Guernica, Gernikako arbola 1891.jpg|thumb|160px|left|Guernica oak, 1890s]] Throughout the entire Bilbao period Irujo maintained close links with Navarre<ref>in 1901 Irujo was emong co-founders of Circulo Navarro in Bilbao and entered its Junta Directiva; he also remained inscriptred into the Pamplona Colegio de Abogados in Pamplona, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 77, 85. His visits were acknowledged in the Navarrese press, see ''El Eco de Navarra'' 17.06.00, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=6010220&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and with Estella. Around 1904 he returned to his native city; exact reasons remain unclear and perhaps are related to taking care of local family business.<ref>Irujo owned some robadas of land near Estella, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 219; upon return he was growing vineyards, Anasagasti 1975, p. 16</ref> He re-entered the local Carlist círculo; around that time the Carlist jefe in Vascongadas, [[Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal|Tirso Olazábal]],<ref>the issue is not entirely clear. Olazábal was the Carlist jefe in Vascongadas ,but not in Navarre, where the leader at the time was Francisco Martinez, Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis Complutense], Madrid 2012, p. 443</ref> offered him the party jefatura in the [[:es:Merindad de Estella|merindad of Estella]] and Irujo accepted.<ref>Olazábal’s proposal is mentioned may time in Irujo’s biography, but never with a clear information that he accepted the offer, see Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 10, 15, 90, 153, 156. From the background it might be understood that he did</ref> For the first time he also openly engaged in political strife. In the local realm dominated by the Conservatives<ref>in Estella named Ochoistas, after local Conservative leader Enrique Ochoa Cintora</ref> and the Carlists,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 92</ref> in 1905 he decided to represent the latter when running for the Estella [[ayuntamiento]];<ref>some presented him as independent Carlist , Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 97</ref> PNV at the time did not have its representatives in the area and explicitly banned their sympathizers from voting other parties.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 95</ref> Irujo was successful<ref>the Ochoistas won 5 tickets and the Carlists claimed 3. Possibly both parties closed a political deal beforehand, which guaranteed success of any of their candidates, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 95-96</ref> and though initially his mandate was revoked on procedural ground,<ref>it was raised that Irujo was not resident in Estella and that as juez municipal he was not allowed to be a concejal at the same time. Irujo claimed he was resident and that as juez he was allowed to stand. Indeed, soon – and unlike his father 40 years earlier – he resigned his juez assignement, ''El Eco de Navarra'' 06.12.05, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=6007631&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he was eventually reinstated in early 1906.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 97-8</ref> In line with official requirements, he declared his political affiliation as Carlist.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 90</ref> The first year of his tenure was a routine one,<ref>as a concejal he took part in ayuntamiento stand against the 1906 Ley de Asociaciones, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 107-108</ref> perhaps except minor Carlist political demonstrations he took part in.<ref>when [[Fernando Primo de Rivera]] was nominated minister of war in 1907, the Estella ayuntamiento planned to send him a routine congratulation note. Irujo and the Carlists opposed the motion; Primo was the military leader who drove the Carlists from Estella in 1876, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 226</ref>
In 1908 the Aranista Centro Vasco of Bilbao used the services of Irujo’s brother-in-law Aranzadi to offer the Estella city a [[shoot]] from the [[Guernica oak]], a symbol of vasco-navarrese fueros.<ref>Centro Vasco offered 8 shoots to 8 different ayuntamientos in Vascongadas and Navarre</ref> Irujo passed the proposal to ayuntamiento,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 108</ref> which accepted the offer<ref>the offer itself was by no means unusual. In 1898 the Biscay Diputación Provinvial offered a shoot of the Guernica oak to the Navarrese Diputación Provincial; it was accepted and the shoot was planted, Fuentes Megina 2013, pp. 29-31</ref> and in a pompous ceremony few months later planted the shoot at a patio of a local school.<ref>exact location of the spot where the shoot was planted is not clear. Sources refer to it as "internal patio of Escuelas Pias". The school exists today as the Basque ikastola, yet it seems that the spot is at the courtyard of what is now the nearby Casa de Cultura Fray San Diego; it is not marked anywhow</ref> Navarrese press remained largely sympathetic, but a Liberal daily raised alarm, claiming that the local self-government fuels Basque separatism.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 115-116, 229</ref> As nationwide press followed suit the issue turned into a scandal, especially that the ceremony was marked by Basque and Navarrese flavor with almost total absence of official references to Spain;<ref>e.g. during an evening orchestra concert the same day the only songs played were those from a Basque and Navarrese repertoire, while the invitation letter commenced with "Gora Euzkadi!" When speaking, an invited guest from Centro Vasco made frequent references to "la nación pirenaica" and concluded with "Gora Nabarra! Gora Euzkadi!"</ref> moderate Irujo’s address<ref>Irujo he was specifically asked by the mayor, who at the last minute developed some anxiety about "certain flavor" of the planned feast, to avoid controversial and personal references. According to some scholars, it was the reason why he mentioned neither Carlism nor Llorens. On the other hand, some claim that Irujo most likely mentioned Arana in his address, Arantzazu Ametzaga Iribarren, ''El árbol de Gernika en Nabarra'', [in:] ''Noticias de Navarra'' 15.02.17, available [http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2017/02/15/opinion/tribunas/el-arbol-de-gernika-en-nabarra here]</ref> was interrupted by angry "Viva España!" cries from the disgusted crowd.<ref>perhaps the most controversial passage of Irujo’s address was his reference to "treason of Maroto", the 1839 accord concluded by the Carlist leader general Maroto with the governmental commander. It was at this point that several vivas to España were heard, apparently in disapproval of Irujo’s comments, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 112, 114, Fuentes Megina 2013, pp. 40-42</ref> The council declared they had been unaware that the shoot originated from Centro Vasco and suggested having been maneuvered into a separatist affair, blaming Aranzadi and Irujo for the miscommunication. [[File:Estella-Lizarra 01.JPG|thumb|Estella]] At the council sittings and in the press Irujo claimed that ayuntamiento was perfectly aware of the shoot origins,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 126</ref> yet his arguments were rejected. The shoot was sent back to Centro Vasco and replaced by new ones, officially provided by the Biscay diputación.<ref>some suggests that the Estella council was genuinely concerned that shoots provided originally were not original, Fuentes Megina 2013, p. 42</ref> They were planted 3 weeks after the first ceremony. The re-implantation was an equally public though somewhat less pompous event; this time the Spanish and Navarrese features were carefully balanced, while the Basque ones were absent.<ref>the original implantation took place on March 15, 1908. The second one took place on April 8, 1908. Among flags of Spain and vivas to España, Marcha Real was played a number of times, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 140. Exact fate of the shoot is not clear; according to one source, it grew into a tree and at unspecified time and in unspecified circumstances it was cut down. Another tree was planted in 2004, but it was cut down by unknown perpetrators in 2009, compare ''Hispanismo'' service, available [http://hispanismo.org/navarra/10428-talan-hachazos-un-retono-del-arbol-de-guernica-en-estella.html here]. Some identify the culprits as "fanaticos Navarristas", see e.g. Xabier Zabaltza, ''Gernikako arbola, un himno huerfano'', [in:] ''Historia Contemporánea'' 54 (2017), p. 235. This would suggest that the oak keeps generating political controversies, in this case related to Navarrismo and its opposition to Basque nationalism</ref> Embittered with the city council blaming him for the affair, in the immediate aftermath Irujo ceased to attend its sittings, excusing himself for the absence.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 155</ref> Later in 1908 the ayuntamiento admitted he was right, but this did not make Irujo change his mind. In early 1909 the mayor and his deputy resigned; technically, as segundo teniente de alcalde Irujo was becoming the interim [[alcalde]]. At this point he formally resigned his counselor mandate and did not stand in the successive elections of May 1909.
==From Carlist to Nationalist== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard from 1935]] Initially the Carlist ''[[:es:El Pensamiento Navarro|El Pensamiento Navarro]]'' acknowledged the first implantation with sympathy, praising the homage to "nuestras libertades tradicionales" and complaining only about lack of Irujo’s references to Carlist champions of Navarrese rights like Llorens.<ref>according to some scholars Irujo did not mention Llorens in his address complying with the mayor’s request to avoid controversial political references, and the Carlist press was perfectly aware of that, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 114, 124, Fuentes Megina 2013, p. 42</ref> However, soon the party press – especially in Vascongadas – assumed a hostile tone; the Gipuzkoan ''[[:es:La Voz de Guipúzcoa|La Voz de Guipúzcoa]]'' lambasted Irujo as "concejal reaccionario"<ref>this tag was later repeated by other titles elsewhere, see e.g. a Valencian daily ''El Pueblo'', 17.03.08, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1000180918&presentacion=pagina here], or as "individuo muy significado por sus tendencias reaccionarias", ''La Correspondencia Militar'' 17.03.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001958309&page=1 here]</ref> and ''[[:es:El Correo de Guipúzcoa|El Correo de Guipúzcoa]]'' linked the event to venomous anti-Spanish separatism.<ref>including groups advancing the "muera España" cries, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 127-8</ref> Carlist circles<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 121</ref> and provincial leaders<ref>on March 27 the Carlist tycoon [[José María de Orbe y Gaytán|marqués de Valdespina]] congratulated the ayuntamiento for their "entusiasmo el patriótico acuerdo", ending his address with "vivas a España y a Euskeria", Fuentes Megina 2013, p. 41</ref> were sending messages congratulating the ayuntamiento on their decision to send the original shoot back. Another Carlist in the council, Nicanor Larráinzar Senosiáin, led an all-out charge on Irujo, also publicly,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 117, 133</ref> claiming that his support for the Aranistas was incompatible with Carlism.<ref>both Irujo and Larráinar address their opened letters to their opponents, virulently listing their official titles as received "por gracia de su Majestad don Alfonso XIII", Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 145. Such a phrase, normally quite innocent, sounded like an insult when penned by a Carlist</ref> Irujo denied separatist charges, charged his opponent with political opportunism<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 142-143</ref> and initially confirmed his Carlist identity. Things changed when Tirso Olazábal congratulated Larráinzar on his stand.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 148</ref> In a public letter to Olazábal Irujo considered himself disauthorised; speculating that apparently he had been erroneous as to fuerista objectives of the Carlists, he declared leaving Carlism.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 156</ref>
In a letter to Luis Arana Irujo proclaimed that from then on he would not be any "carlo-bizkaitarra", but "nacionalista vasco a secas".<ref>"en Bilbao me llamaban carlo-bizkaitarra y tenían razón; ahora no tengo nada de cario, y me abrazo en cuerpo y alma a Jel [Jaungoikoa Eta Lagizarrak], sin aditamento de ningún género", quoted after Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 157, see also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TCN56ZUSD0 here]</ref> However, when in late 1908 offered a post in Navarrese Partido Nacionalista Vasco structures, he declined. The reasons are not clear. Some scholars speculate that aware of growing controversy between Arana and Aranzadi, Irujo could have not brought himself to taking a stand; another reason might have been growing rivalry between a radical Navarrese wing of Evangelista de Ibero<ref>padre Evangelista de Ibero, who nurtured strongly anti-Carlist views, remained on close terms at least with Irujo’s sons, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 88</ref> and a more moderate one championed by his brother-in-law.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 158-9, 160-161</ref> Nevertheless, he remained in touch with PNV activists both in Navarre and in [[Biscay]]. When their new Navarrese periodical ''Napartarra'' was launched in 1911, Irujo featured as one of its collaborators.<ref>''Napartarra'', [in:] ''Gran Enciclopedia Navarra'' online , available [http://www.enciclopedianavarra.com/?page_id=15072 here]</ref> Some students speculate that had it not been for his premature death,<ref>Irujo and his wife developed pneumonia; she got better but he did not, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 164</ref> Irujo would have represented the Nationalists in forthcoming elections.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 163</ref> [[File:Flag of the Basque Country alternative proportions.svg|thumb|[[ikurriña]]]] One scholar concludes that indeed, apparent Irujo’s attempt to match Nationalist and Carlist objectives was mission impossible.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 15</ref> He identifies Irujo's political position as "radical fuerismo",<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 157</ref> its essence being reversal to pre-1839 regime.<ref>García-Sanz Marcotegui 2002, p. 23</ref> Deprived of anti-Spanish venom<ref>e.g. in 1901, when organizing San Fermín feast in Circulo Navarro in Bilbao, he ended th event with Vivas to España, for which he was later criticised by militant Basque press, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 78</ref> and far from classic separatism, it envisioned Vasco-Navarrese area as sovereign entities united with other Spanish political bodies by a common monarch. It also did not include "los aspectos más negativos del aranismo", i.e. racism.<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 17</ref> It is not clear to what extent Irujo embraced [[nationalism]] as emerging in Europe of the time. He certainly acknowledged and appreciated separated Basque identity, yet it seems that his vision of Basque commonality was based on geography, religion,<ref>Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 203; he sent a postcarcd with sagrado corazón to his nephew and brought up own children in religious zeal</ref> history and culture rather than on ethnicity.<ref>claiming that the only ambition of "nacionalidades vascas" was return to pre-1839 rule, Irujo noted also that "en una palabra, todo cuanto una nación necesita para regirse y gobernarse por sí sin injerencias extrañas aunque constituya parte integrante de un Estado compuesto de nacionalidades distintas", Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 145</ref> On the other hand, he hailed the newly invented icon of Basque nationalism, [[ikurriña]],<ref>referred to as "shroud which covers all Basques", Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 81-82</ref> and called for unification of all Basques in "tierra euzkeriana". Another scholar considers Irujo a typical case of transitory identity from Carlism<ref>according to a contemporary scholar, the Carlists of the time boasted restoration of fueros as their war cry, but in fact they adjourned it ad calendas graecas, and approached it mostly as means of mobilizing support, Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, p. 11. As one of the fuerista activists put it, before their own advent "la reintegración foral era un sueño dorado; nadie pensaba que pudiera llegar a ser una realidad. Confesémoslo: éramos fueristas, pero no teníamos fe, no teníamos esperanza. Bastaba para satisfacer nuestra conciencia afirmar el deseo de la reintegración foral y precisar bien el alcance de nuestro deseo", Garcia-Sanz Marcotegui 1995, pp. 11-12</ref> to peripheral nationalism,<ref>he also summarised Irujo’s political trajectory somewhat differently, namely that "carlista en sus orígenes, evolucionó hacia el nacionalismo vasco a finales del siglo xix, para regresar, a principios del Novecientos, a la órbita carlista", Jordi Canal, ''¿En busca del precedente perdido? Tríptico sobre las complejas relaciones entre carlismo y catalanismo a fines del siglo XIX'', [in:] ''Historia y Politica'' 14 (2005), p. 66</ref> parallel to those of [[Marian Vayreda i Vila|Vayreda]] (Catalonia), [[:es:Alfredo Brañas|Brañas]] (Galicia) and [[José María de Pereda|Pereda]] (Cantabria).<ref>Canal 2005, p. 62, Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo. Dos siglos de contrarrevolución en España'', Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|9788420639475}}, p. 249, Jordi Canal, ''Marian Vayreda, entre el carlisme i el catalánisme'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 225 (2004), p. 45</ref> One more author considers Irujo irrelevant when discussing relations between "fuerismo [[Traditionalism (Spain)|tradicionalista]]" and "nacionalismo vasco".<ref>in a dedicated thesis specifically discussing mutual relations between fuerismo of Carlist origin and the nascent Basque nationalism, focused on the turn of the centuries, Irujo is not mentioned a single time, see José Ignacio Fínez García, ''Fuerismo tradicionalista]] y nacionalismo vasco'' [MA thesis Universidad de Salamanca], Salamanca 2013</ref>

'''Isabella ''' "'''Ella'''" ''' Robertson Christie''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|FRSGS|FSAS|FRGS}} (21 April 1861 - 29 January 1949) was a pioneering Scottish traveller and explorer, landowner, gardener and author.
==Early life== Christie was born on 21 April 1861 at Millbank in [[Cockpen, Midlothian|Cockpen]], near Bonnyrigg, to Alison (née Philp, c.1817–1894) and [[John Christie (landowner)|John Christie]] (1824–1902), a Scottish industrialist and landowner. Christie had an elder brother, John Coldwells who died in childhood in his twelfth year in 1872,<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title = 'Alicella': a memoir of Alice King Stewart and Ella Christie|last = Stewart|first = Averill|publisher = John Murray|year = 1955|isbn = |location = London|pages = 4}}</ref> and a younger sister, Alice Margaret.<ref name=":5" /> In 1865 Christie's father purchased the Castleton estate in the [[Ochil Hills|Ochils]], renaming it Cowden Castle, and the family moved there. Christie and her sister were educated at home by her parents and governesses. From an early age she made annual trips with her parents to Europe including [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[Germany]] and the [[Low Countries]]. After her mother's death and her sister's marriage Christie continued to travel with her father and also alone or with a friend. She visited [[Egypt]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] and [[Syria]] and started to write about her trips.
On her father's death in 1902 it was found that he had disinherited both Christie and her sister, leaving the entirety of his estate to an orphanage that he had founded without their knowledge. They contested the will and in 1903 it was settled with the estate being divided between the two sisters and the orphanage. Ella lived on at Cowden Castle and managed the estate.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Isabella Christie|url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/55607|website = www.oxforddnb.com|access-date = 2016-01-16|last = Baker|first = Anne Pimlott|date = 2004|publisher = Oxford University Press}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = The Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs6qBgAAQBAJ|publisher = Edinburgh University Press|date = 2006-03-08|isbn = 9780748626601|first = Elizabeth L.|last = Ewan|first2 = Sue|last2 = Innes|first3 = Sian|last3 = Reynolds|first4 = Rose|last4 = Pipes}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Gardening Women: Their Stories From 1600 to the Present|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RKqMMceJjukC|publisher = Little, Brown Book Group|date = 2010-05-06|isbn = 9780748118335|first = Catherine|last = Horwood}}</ref>
== Travels == After her father's death Christie's travels became more ambitious and she began to travel more widely. From 1904 to 1905 she travelled with her maid, Humphries, initially to India and then on to [[Kashmir]], [[Tibet]], [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]], [[Malay Peninsula|Malaya]] and [[Borneo]]. Being well connected and carrying letters of introduction she attended a banquet with the [[maharaja]] of Kashmir and dined with [[Herbert Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]]. Her adventures saw her camping in the snow at [[Chorbat Valley|Chorbat Pass]], sailing in a cargo ship full of pigs, travelling by pack horse and cart in the Kashmir wilderness and trekking by foot for 60 miles in the [[Deosai Mountains|Desoi mountains]].<ref name=":0" />
In 1907 she visited China, Korea and Japan. While in Japan Christie was fascinated by the Japanese formal style of gardening, an interest that would inspire her to create a Japanese garden at Cowden Castle.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
In 1910 she packed a camp bed, stove, lamp, oatmeal and biscuits and travelled to [[Russian Turkestan]]. Her journey took her to [[Constantinople]] across the [[Black Sea]], through [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] to the [[Caspian Sea]] and onwards to [[Ashgabat|Ashkabad]] and [[Merv]]. She travelled by train and boat along the [[Silk Road]], visiting [[Bukhara|Buhkhara]], [[Samarkand]], [[Kokand]], and finally to [[Andijan|Andhizan.]]<ref name=":0" />
Christie undertook a further trip to the [[Russian Empire]] in 1912. Starting in [[Saint Petersburg]] she travelled by train, steamer and [[droshky]] to [[Tashkent]], Samarkand and [[Khiva]]. She was the first British woman to ever visit Khiva.<ref name=":0" />
In 1914 she visited the United States and Cuba.<ref name=":0" />
Christie kept an account of her travels in her diaries and she was in regular correspondence with her sister. She later wrote about her trips to the Russian Empire in the book ''Through Khiva to golden Samarkand''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Isabella Christie|url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/55607|website = www.oxforddnb.com|access-date = 2016-01-16|last = Baker|first = Anne Pimlott|date = 2004|publisher = Oxford University Press}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = The Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs6qBgAAQBAJ|publisher = Edinburgh University Press|date = 2006-03-08|isbn = 9780748626601|first = Elizabeth L.|last = Ewan|first2 = Sue|last2 = Innes|first3 = Sian|last3 = Reynolds|first4 = Rose|last4 = Pipes}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Gardening Women: Their Stories From 1600 to the Present|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RKqMMceJjukC|publisher = Little, Brown Book Group|date = 2010-05-06|isbn = 9780748118335|first = Catherine|last = Horwood}}</ref>
== World War I == In 1916, Christie travelled to France to become the manager of the ''L'Oeuvre de la Goutte de Café'' at [[Bar-sur-Aube]]. This network of cafés was established by the French and [[British Red Cross]] as a places for tired soldiers to relax and rest.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Full text of "For dauntless France, an account of Britain's aid to the French wounded and victims of the war;"|url = https://archive.org/stream/fordauntlessfran00biny/fordauntlessfran00biny_djvu.txt|website = archive.org|access-date = 2016-01-17|pages = 190–191}}</ref> The café that Christie managed was staffed by five Scottish women and served the soldiers fighting at the [[Battle of Verdun]]. From 1918-1919 Christie oversaw another ''<nowiki/>'LOuevre de la Goutte de Café'' at [[Mulhouse|Mul]][[Mulhouse|house]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = The Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs6qBgAAQBAJ|publisher = Edinburgh University Press|date = 2006-03-08|isbn = 9780748626601|first = Elizabeth L.|last = Ewan|first2 = Sue|last2 = Innes|first3 = Sian|last3 = Reynolds|first4 = Rose|last4 = Pipes}}</ref>
== Japanese garden at Cowden Castle == After her visit to Japan in 1907 Christie was inspired to create a seven-acre [[Japanese garden]] at her home at Cowden Castle. She employed Taki Handi, from the Royal School of Garden Design in Nagoya, to help plan and design the garden. The [[Stream|burn]] on the estate was dammed and a hollow made to create an artificial [[loch]] and a pond and island garden was developed along with a stroll garden and a tea-house garden. Plants, shrubs, trees and a traditional stone lantern were imported from Japan. The garden was named ''Shāh-raku-en'' meaning a place of pleasure or delight.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
Christie was advised on the form, maintenance and development of the garden by Professor Jijo Soya Suzuki, Master of the Soami School of Imperial Design. Suzuki considered the garden to the best Japanese garden in the Western world. Shinzaburo Matsuo lived and worked at Cowden as gardener from 1925 until his death in 1937. [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]] visited the garden in the late 1930s.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Recognition for Japanese garden at Cowden Castle|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-23970528|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-17}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title = The Japanese Garden at Cowden Castle|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2i2IMYh_kT0|date = 2014-09-22|accessdate = 2016-01-17}}</ref>
After Christie's death in 1949 the garden was maintained by workers on the Cowden estate. In 1963 it was vandalised and the teahouses and bridges were burned and the lanterns and shrines knocked into the loch.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url = http://www.fineartcommissions.com/cowden/pdf/the-japanese-garden-at-cowden-castle-restoration-appeal.pdf|title = The Japanese Garden, Cowden Castle, Scotland. A restoration appeal|last = Stewart|first = Sara|date = 2014|work = |access-date = 17 January 2015|via = }}</ref>
In 2014 Christie's great great niece Sara Stewart started a fundraising campaign to raise £1,000,000 to restore the garden.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = Historic Scotland {{!}} The Japanese Garden at Cowden Castle|url = http://www.fineartcommissions.com/cowden/historic-scotland.html|website = www.fineartcommissions.com|access-date = 2016-01-17}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Fellowships == Christie was a fellow [[Royal Scottish Geographical Society|Royal Geographical Society of Scotland]], she was a member of council and in November 1934 she became a vice-president of the Society.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://search.proquest.com/hnpscotsman/docview/480922177/4039BFFC3B7E44F7PQ|title = Geographical Society|date = 1 November 1935|access-date = 16 January 2016|website = The Scotsman newspaper archive 1921-1950|publisher = Proquest|last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Royal Scottish geographical society proceedings|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00369224908735405|journal = Scottish Geographical Magazine|date = 1949-04-01|issn = 0036-9225|pages = 63–64|volume = 65|issue = 1|doi = 10.1080/00369224908735405}}</ref> She was also a Fellow of the [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland]].<ref name=":0" />
On 15 January 1913 the [[Royal Geographical Society]] voted to allow women to be elected to become members of the Society. On 10 February 1913 Christie was in the first cohort of women to be elected Fellows.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Admission of Women Fellows to the Royal Geographical Society, 1892-1914; the Controversy and the Outcome|jstor = 3059652|journal = The Geographical Journal|date = 1996-01-01|pages = 295–312|volume = 162|issue = 3|doi = 10.2307/3059652|first = Morag|last = Bell|first2 = Cheryl|last2 = McEwan}}</ref>
== Death == Christie died of [[leukemia]] on the 29 January 1949 at Strathearn Road, Edinburgh.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" />
== Books == Christie authored and co-authored several books about her travels, two of which she wrote with her sister, Alice.<ref>{{Cite web|title = WorldCat.org|url = http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=au%253AChristie%252C+Ella+R.&fq=&dblist=638&qt=sort&se=yr&sd=asc&qt=sort_yr_asc|website = www.worldcat.org|access-date = 2016-01-16}}</ref> * ''Fairy tales from Finland'' / Zacharias Topelius, Ella R. Christie, Ada Holland. London : Unwin, 1896. * ''Fare and physic of a past century'' / Ella R. Christie and Alice M. Stewart. Edinburgh : [[David Douglas (publisher)|David Douglas]], 1900. * ''A summer ride through western Tibet'' / Jane Ellen Duncan, August Hermann Francke, Hayward Porter, Herman B Marx, Ella R. Christie. London : Smith, Elder & Co., 1906. * ''Ratione receipts [of ye great warre] : in aid of the Scottish Red Cross'' / Ella R. Christie. Edinburgh : Thomas Allan, 1918. * ''Through Khiva to golden Samarkand; the remarkable story of a woman's adventurous journey alone through the deserts of Central Asia to the heart of Turkestan'' / Ella R. Christie. London : Seeley, Service & Co., 1925. * ''Ration recipes'' / Ella R. Christie. Edinburgh : Thomas Allan, 1939. * ''A long look at life : by two victorians'' / Ella R. Christie and Alice M. Stewart. London : Seeley, Service & Co., 1940.

(1911) - TIMEA.jpg|thumb|275px|Fellahin in Gizeh, Cairo (1911)]] '''Fellah''' ({{lang-ar|فلاح}}, fallāḥ; plural ''Fellaheen'' or ''Fellahin'', {{lang-ar|فلاحين}}, fallāḥīn) is a farmer or agricultural laborer in the [[Middle East]] and [[North Africa]]. The word derives from the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] word for "ploughman" or "tiller".
A fellah could be seen wearing a simple cotton robe called ''galabieh'' ([[jellabiya]]). The word ''Galabieh'' originated around 1715–25 and derived from the Egyptian Arabic word ''gallabīyah'' (جلابية).
==Origins and usage== Fellahin was the term used throughout the Middle East in the Ottoman period and later to refer to villagers and farmers.<ref>{{cite book|title=Yemen Into the Twenty-First Century: Continuity and Change|first1=Kamil A.|last1=Mahdi|first2=Anna|last2=Würth|first3=Helen|last3=Lackner|publisher=Garnet & Ithaca Press|year=2007|page=209|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v1Mebwe9R_AC&pg=PA209&dq=fellahin}}</ref> [[Nur-eldeen Masalha]] translates it as "peasants,".<ref>{{cite book|title=Catastrophe Remembered: Palestine, Israel and the Internal Refugees: Essays in Memory of Edward W. Said (1935-2003)|first=Nur|last=Masalha|publisher=Zed Books|year=2005|page=78}}</ref>
Fellahin were distinguished from the ''[[effendi]],'' or, land-owning class,<ref>''State Lands and Rural Development in mandatory Palestine, 1920–1948'', Warwick P. N. Tyler, Sussex Academic Press, 2001, p. 13</ref> although the fellahin in this region might be tenant farmers, smallholders, or live in a village that owned the land communally.<ref>[[Hillel Cohen]], [[Army of Shadows, Palestinian Collaboration with Zionism, 1917–1948]], University of California Press, 2008, p. 32</ref><ref>''Healing the Land and the Nation: Malaria and the Zionist Project in Palestine, 1920–1947'', Sandra Marlene Sufian, University of Chicago Press, 2007, p. 57</ref> Others applied the term ''fellahin'' only to landless workers.<ref>Lords of the Lebanese Marches: Violence and Narrative in an Arab Society, Michael Gilsenan, I.B.Tauris, 2003, p. 13</ref> The term ''fallahin'' applied to [[Christianity|Christian]], [[Druze]], [[Musta'arabi Jews|Jewish]] and [[Muslim]] villagers.<ref>{{cite book|title=Syria and the Holy Land|first1=George Adam|last1=Smith|publisher=George H. Doran company|year=1918|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=myEYAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA41&dq=fellahin+syria}}</ref> The term ''fallah'' was applied to people from several regions in the [[Middle East]], including those of [[Egypt]], [[Levant]], [[Iraq]] and [[Cyprus]].
==Fellahin in Egypt== Comprising 60% of the Egyptian population in both Lower and Upper Egypt,<ref>''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080514092415re_rn_1/www.semp.us/publications/biot_reader.php?BiotID=312 Who are the Fellahin? – Biot #312: December 24, 2005]''. SEMP, Inc.</ref> the fellahin lead humble lives and continue to live in mud-brick houses like their ancient ancestors.<ref name="pate">{{cite book|author=Pateman, Robert & Salwa El-Hamamsy|title=Egypt|date=2003|publisher=Marshall Cavendish Benchmark|place=New York|page=54|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2FIvzA6RIHsC&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=fellahin&source=bl&ots=TCqR82cW3U&sig=YaRj6HUm6nANUbAO2reTj8rzNBU&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj597CPzMPVAhVDLVAKHeAKBYw4ChDoAQhXMAc#v=onepage&q=fellahin&f=false}}</ref> Their percentage was much higher in the early 20th century, before the large influx of Egyptian fellahin into urban towns and cities. In 1927, anthropologist Winifred Blackman, author of ''The Fellahin of Upper Egypt'', conducted [[ethnographic]] research on the life of Upper Egyptian farmers and concluded that there were observable continuities between the cultural and religious beliefs and practices of the fellahin and those of ancient Egyptians.<ref name="note5">{{cite news|first=Caryll|last=Faraldi|title=A genius for hobnobbing|date=11–17 May 2000|publisher=Al-Ahram Weekly|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/Archive/2000/481/bk3_481.htm}}</ref>

Princess Bendara | residence = [[Kraton Ngayogyakarta Hadiningrat|The Royal Palace of Yogyakarta]] | alma_mater = [[Gadjah Mada University]] | term_start = 3 October 1998 | term_start1 = 7 March 1989 | module = {{Infobox royalty|embed=yes | name = | title = | titletext = | more = | type = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | successor = [[Princess Mangkubumi]] | suc-type = Heiress presumptive | regent = | reg-type = | house = [[Hamengkubuwono]] | house-type = }} }} {{Yogyakarta Royal Family}} '''Sri Sultan Hamengkubuwono X''' (also spelled as '''Hamengkubuwana X''', often abbreviated as '''HB X''') (born BRM Herjuno Darpito, 2 April 1946 in [[Yogyakarta]]) is the [[Sultan]] of the historic [[Yogyakarta Sultanate]] in [[Indonesia]], and is currently also the [[Governor]] of the modern [[Yogyakarta Special Region]] (''Daerah Istimewa Yogyakarta''). Hamengkubuwono X succeeded his father, [[Hamengkubuwono IX]] as the Sultan of Yogyakarta when Hamengkubuwono IX died on 3 October 1988. Hamengkubuwono X was formally installed as Sultan on 7 March 1989. However, the position of the Governor of the Yogyakarta Special Region did not go to Hamengkubuwono X. Vice Governor [[Sri Paku Alam VIII]], prince of the subordinate enclave of [[Paku Alaman]] within Yogyakarta was instead controversially elevated to the position of governor. This was in contrary to the agreement made at the independence of Indonesia in recognition of Hamengkubuwono IX's support and role in the Indonesian War of Independence. Under the agreement, the Yogyakarta Sultan holds the position of governor in the Yogyakarta Special Region, and the Paku Alam holds the position of vice governor. After the fall of the [[Suharto]] regime in May 1998, and following the death of Sri Paku Alam VIII on 11 September 1998, the central government required an election be held for the post of Yogyakarta Governor. Hamengkubuwono X was democratically elected as the Governor on 3 October 1998.{{cn|date=March 2017}} On 30 August 2012, following a decade of talks between Yogyakarta and the central government, the [[People's Consultative Assembly|national legislature of Indonesia]] formally enshrined in law the convention that the Sultan inherits the position of governor.{{cite web |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/banyan/2012/09/yogyakartas-sultans |title= Yogyakarta's sultans — Carrying on|last1= N.O. |first1= |date=2012-09-06 |website=[[The Economist]] |publisher= |accessdate=2014-12-08}} ==Background== Hamengkubuwono X was a graduate of Public Administration at the Faculty of Law of [[Gajah Mada University]] in [[Yogyakarta (city)|Yogyakarta]]. Hamengkubuwono X was active as Chairman DIY KADINDAII (Business Association), Chairman of the DPD Golkar DIY (Golongan Karya Party Yogyakarta), Chairman of the DIY Sports Committee Chairman and Managing Director of PT Punokawan Construction, President of the PG Madukismo Commissioner, and in July 1996 was appointed Chairman of the DIY Expert Counsel to the Governor. Hamengkubuwono X followed the tradition of his late father Sri Sultan Hamengkubuwono IX in the spirit of Indonesian Nationalism over self-interest by participating in street protests in support of the student demonstrations opposing Suharto's rule on May 14 of 1998, and like his illustrious father, wanted to be a pioneer in the Yogyakarta Reformation Movement albeit in a non-violent manner. Hamengkubuwono X was also one of the four key figures in the early reform period sparked Ciganjur Declaration urging the government to hold elections as soon as possible, because President [[BJ Habibie]] had neither [[Constitutional]] nor legal right to resume the presidency of Suharto who had just resigned. Hamengkubuwono X has stated his vision for his region and Sultanate is the development of science and technology, development of agriculture, tourism and world-famous cultural industries and thus provide a fair and prosperous life to all his citizens. Hamengkubuwono X was nominated by popular choice, Golkar Yogyakarta Assembly as a Presidential Candidate for the 2009 Indonesian Presidential Election Campaign. Hamengkubuwono X, though widely respected across all parties and nationwide as neutral, honest and uncorrupted was ultimately unsuccessful in garnering support outside [[Central Java]] and was unsuccessful to attain first round voting position. ==Personal life== Hamengkubuwono X has discontinued the [[polygamist]] tradition of Javanese royalty with kings having several wives and possible multiple [[concubine]]s, as per his late father's wishes to modernize the royal system and thus women's rights, and to lead by example and is married to [[Ratu]] [[Gusti Kanjeng Ratu (GKR) Hemas]]. Their five daughters (in birth order) are: * Crown Princess [[Princess Mangkubumi|Gusti Kanjeng Ratu Mangkubumi]] (heiress presumptive) married to [[Kanjeng Pangeran Haryo Wironegoro]] * [[Gusti Kanjeng Ratu Condrokirono]] divorced * [[Gusti Kanjeng Ratu Maduretno]] married to [[Kanjeng Pangeran Haryo Purbodiningrat]] * [[Gusti Kanjeng Ratu Hayu]] married to [[Kanjeng Pangeran Haryo Notonegoro]] * [[Gusti Kanjeng Ratu Bendara]] married to [[Kanjeng Pangeran Haryo Yudonegoro]] [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Inhuldiging van Sultan Hamengku Buwana X in de kraton met naast hem de Gusti Kanjeng Ratu Hemas TMnr 20018311.jpg|thumb|Coronation of Hamengkubuwono X and Hemas in 1989|alt=|left]]Hamengkubuwono X resides in the Keraton Yogyakarta complex and uses the Governor's mansion solely for political affairs. ==Titles== {{Infobox royal styles |royal name = Hamengkubuwono X |image = |dipstyle = His Highness |offstyle = Your Highness |altstyle = ''Ngarso Dalem''}} In Javanese
